pageContext.claim: “One thing that's different with the president, I had dinner with the queen. I had -- I met with the prime minister of the U.K. I was with the head of France. I was with the head of all these nations and I constantly am, constantly talking to them. And, you know, that puts us in a different -- we -- we have many, many conversations. And I'm just thinking, gee, if they say, we don't like your opponent, am I supposed to put -- you know, the president of France, am I supposed to report him to the FBI?”
pageContext.analysis: Trump was asked whether he would report to the FBI any efforts from foreign powers to assist his reelection campaign. The president responded with a false comparison. Even if a foreign leader expressed disapproval for one of Trump's opponents, that's hardly the same as what happened in 2016: Russia orchestrated a sophisticated hacking and cyber-propaganda campaign to help Trump win, and the Trump campaign welcomed that help and sought to exploit it, though there was not enough evidence to charge a conspiracy, according to special counsel Robert Mueller.
